title: Identify the Variables
text: Consider the number of moles present in each vessel and what impact it has on the heat capacity. More moles might imply a greater change in energy under a constant heating process.

title: Use the Heat Capacity Formula
text: Recall the formula for calculating heat. For a given amount of substance, heat Q can be represented as $$Q=nC_{v}\Delta T$$, where $$n$$ is moles, $$C_v$$ is specific heat capacity at constant volume and ΔT is the change in temperature.

title: Consider Specific Heat Capacities
text: Different gases have different specific heat capacities at constant volume $$C_v$$. For ideal gases, the specific heat capacity can be calculated based on whether the gas is monatomic or diatomic. For ideal gases, monatomic gases (like $$He$$ and $$Ne$$), typically have $$C_v = \frac{3}{2}R$$, while diatomic gases (like $$H_2$$ and $$N_2$$) generally have $$C_v = \frac{5}{2}R$$, where $$R$$ is the gas constant. Using these $$C_v$$ values will help you understand the heat $$Q$$ each gas absorbs under the heating process. Determine the $$C_v$$ values for these gases to understand their heating behavior.

title: Analyze the Expressed Relationships
text: Based on the calculated heat values, if $$Q_{s_1}$$ < $$Q_{s_2}$$ then vessel $$1$$ absorbs less heat than vessel $$2$$ and so forth. Formulate the final ranking order.
